questions.text: The ___ folder in the Package Explorer of an Android application project contains amongst others the image, music and video files.
questions.explanation: The assets/ folder is used for bundled raw files such as images, audio, and video that are read via the AssetManager.

questions.text: The ___ folder in the Package Explorer of an Android application project contains the code source files.
questions.explanation: Application source code is stored in the src/ directory (or the java/ directory in newer projects).

questions.text: The ___ package in Java provides classes for performing arithmetic operations.
questions.explanation: Classes such as BigInteger and BigDecimal for high-precision arithmetic live in the java.math package.

questions.text: In an Android application the ___ class executes first in an application, regardless of where you physically place it within a project.
questions.explanation: The launcher activity configured in the manifest starts first. In typical templates this is MainActivity.

questions.text: The ___ data type is used to hold any single character.
questions.explanation: A Java char stores a single UTF-16 code unit and is the appropriate type for an individual character.

questions.text: Locating and repairing errors in programs is part of the process of ___ a program.
questions.explanation: Debugging is the act of finding and correcting logic errors or defects in code.

questions.text: ___ are pieces of information that are passed to a method that will enable the method to perform its task.
questions.explanation: Arguments are the actual values supplied when invoking a method so it can perform its work.

questions.text: In Java, the reserved keyword ___ means that a method is accessible and usable even if no objects of the class exist.
questions.explanation: static members belong to the class itself and can be accessed without creating an instance.
public is the access modifier, indicating the method is callable from any class.

questions.text: Which one of the following is a correct keyword used for handling exceptions in Java?
questions.explanation: Exception handling uses keywords such as try, catch, finally, throw, and throws.

questions.text: Which one of the following is NOT one of the components of a method header?
options: (2) The return type for the method
questions.explanation: A constructor is a special member distinct from regular method headers.
Using == to compare Strings compiles but produces the wrong outcome, which is a logic error.

questions.text: Indicate which one of the following lines of code has a syntax error. 1. boolean outcome = TRUE; 2. int test1 = '1'; 3. double solution = 1.234e2; 4. float budget = 1.23f; 5. long result = 123_456_789;
questions.explanation: Boolean literals are lowercase true/false; using TRUE is a syntax error.
The int value A is promoted to double, so 5 / 10.0 yields 0.5.

questions.text: Which of the following declarations will render an error?
questions.explanation: Casting 1.3 to double still leaves a double literal, which cannot be assigned to a float without an explicit cast to float.

options: (1) try { fahrenheit = celcius * convert + 32; } catch (Exception e) {}
(2) try { fahrenheit = celcius * convert + 32; } catch () { Exception e; }
(3) try { fahrenheit = celcius * convert + 32; } catch (e) { Exception e; }
(4) try { fahrenheit = celcius * convert + 32; } catch (Exception) { Exception = e; }
questions.correctAnswer: (1) try { fahrenheit = celcius * convert + 32; } catch (Exception e) {}
questions.explanation: Option 1 is the only syntactically correct try/catch block among the choices.

questions.text: (i) The user enters the following code. What will be the value of total after the code is executed? ```java total = sum(val1, val2, val3); ``` Use the supplied class skeleton where val1 is an uninitialised local variable and overloaded sum methods exist.
options: (2) The code executes but the first sum method refers to val4.
(3) The code will not compile because the first method refers to val4.
(4) The code will not compile as val1 is not initialised.
questions.correctAnswer: (4) The code will not compile as val1 is not initialised.
questions.explanation: Local variables must be assigned before use, so val1 triggers a compile-time error.

options: (3) The code will not compile as you cannot change the value of val3 because it is static.
(4) The code will not compile as sum(val1, val3) has no matching method.
questions.explanation: The two-argument sum method is used, so 4 + 20 = 24 after updating the static val3 variable.

options: (3) The code will not compile as both val3 and val4 are static values.
(4) The code will not compile as val4 is declared final.
questions.correctAnswer: (4) The code will not compile as val4 is declared final.
questions.explanation: val4 is a static final constant, so attempting to reassign it results in a compilation error.
The calculation uses floating-point arithmetic and the boolean reflects pass/fail.

options: (1) Nothing will be printed. There is no ELSE statement in the IF statement.
(2) The value of answer will be "Pass" as total is greater than or equal to 50.
(3) The value of answer will be "Fail". After the IF statement the next statement assigns "Fail" to answer.
(4) The value "PassFail" will be allocated to answer.
questions.correctAnswer: (3) The value of answer will be "Fail". After the IF statement the next statement assigns "Fail" to answer.
questions.explanation: The block following the if executes unconditionally, overwriting the earlier assignment.
A String stores the name and the calculation involves floating-point division, best captured by double.

options: (1) private static boolean calc(double e, double y) { boolean a = false; double f = (e + y) / 2; if (f >= 50) { a = true; } return a; }
(2) private static boolean calc(int e, int y) { boolean a = false; int f = (e + y) / 2; if (f < 50) { a = false; } return a; }
(3) private static int calc(int e, int y) { int f = (e + y) / 2; return f; }
(4) private static boolean calc(int e, int y) { boolean pass; int f = (e + y) / 2; if (f >= 50) { pass = true; } else { pass = false; } return pass; }
questions.correctAnswer: (3) private static int calc(int e, int y) { int f = (e + y) / 2; return f; }
questions.explanation: The calling code expects a boolean result, so a method returning int is incompatible.

questions.text: Which one of these is an INCORRECT array declaration?
questions.explanation: You assign to the array variable, not to arr[]. The correct statement would be arr = new int[5];

questions.text: Indicate which one of the following options can replace the array declarations and initialiser statements for modules and levels.
options: (1) String[] modules = new String {"ICT1511", "ICT2611", "ICT3611"}; String[] levels = new String {"1", "2", "3"};
(4) String[3] modules = new String {"ICT1511", "ICT2611", "ICT3611"}; String[3] levels = new String {"1", "2", "3"};
questions.explanation: Array initialiser syntax without new is the concise and correct replacement for explicit assignments.

questions.text: Assume a String array progMods is declared correctly. Indicate which one of the following code snippets will correctly combine the two arrays modules and levels and initialise progMods.
options: (1) for (int i = 0; i < 2; i++) { progMods[i] = modules[i] + " " + levels[i]; }
(2) for (int i = 0; i = 3; i++) { progMods[i] = modules[i] + " " + levels[i]; }
(3) for (int i = 4; i < 0; i--) { students[i] = names[i] + " " + surnames[i]; } for (int i = 0; i = 3; i--) { progMods[i] = modules[i] + " " + levels[i]; }
(4) for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) { progMods[i] = modules[i] + " " + levels[i]; }
questions.correctAnswer: (4) for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) { progMods[i] = modules[i] + " " + levels[i]; }
questions.explanation: Iterating indices 0..2 concatenates the matching entries from both arrays into progMods.

questions.text: Indicate which one of the following code fragments will correctly calculate the length of the array progMods.
questions.explanation: Arrays expose their size through the length field, not a method call.

options: (1) day: 0, hasMore: false, days: sun sat fri thu wed tue mon
questions.explanation: The loop appends while decrementing; the first concatenation produces a "null" prefix and the loop exits after day becomes -1.
The loop sums to 39.0 and the helper divides by 3, yielding 13.0.
The prefix increment makes num equal 4 before multiplication, so result becomes 32.

questions.text: The purpose of the variable numStudents is to keep track of the number of ___.
options: (2) modules that the specific student is enrolled in
(4) students enrolled in a specific module
questions.explanation: numStudents is a static counter incremented each time the Student constructor runs.

questions.text: A Student object has access to variables in the non-static functions of the Student class:
options: (2) String studName, studNum, studId, modCode; String bday, nqf; int level;
(3) String bday, nqf; int level; static int numStudents = 0;
(4) String studName, studNum, studId, modCode; String bday, nqf; int level; static int numStudents = 0;
questions.correctAnswer: (4) String studName, studNum, studId, modCode; String bday, nqf; int level; static int numStudents = 0;
questions.explanation: All class members (instance and static) are accessible from the class's non-static methods.

questions.text: (i) Indicate which of the following will correctly link the variables for the second constructor to the instance variables.
options: (1) name = StudName; studNum = studNum; id = studId; modCode = modCode;
(2) name = this.StudName; studNum = this.studNum; id = this.studId; modCode = this.modCode;
(3) this.studName = name; this.studNum = studNum; this.studId = id; this.modCode = modCode;
(4) None of the above. You cannot have the same instance variable names as the local variable names.
questions.correctAnswer: (3) this.studName = name; this.studNum = studNum; this.studId = id; this.modCode = modCode;
questions.explanation: Using this.field = parameter disambiguates and assigns constructor arguments to instance fields.

questions.text: The method getBday calls a method detMonth. Indicate which of the following code fragments CANNOT be used in detMonth to determine the specific month.
questions.explanation: Adding one to the converted month shifts the index, producing the wrong month string.

questions.text: Indicate which one of the following will fail to create an instance of the class Student.
options: (4) Student stud = new Student(null, null, null, null);
questions.correctAnswer: (4) Student stud = new Student(null, null, null, null);
questions.explanation: Passing null values leads to NullPointerException when methods call substring on the ID.

options: (1) Error message. display must be of type String.
questions.explanation: numStudents is static and increments to 1 after constructing the single Student instance.

options: (1) Error message: studNum must be 13 characters long.
questions.explanation: numStudents equals 1, so the updated studNum becomes 50607080 + "1", producing that email address.

options: (4) None of the above. You cannot do a binary search on a String array.
questions.explanation: The array is sorted alphabetically, so "BMW" is located at index 1 (0-based).
There is no String constructor that accepts a String[]; attempting this causes a compile-time error.

options: (1) Error message: You can only determine the index of one element, not of a string.
questions.explanation: The substring ".co.za" begins at index 13 in the supplied email address.
toUpperCase() returns a new String, so wpm remains the original "above average".

options: (1) public class Figure { double v1, v2; public Figure(double val1, double val2){ this.v1 = val1; this.v2 = val2; } public Figure() { } public double getArea() { return v1 * v2; } }
(2) public class Figure { double v1, v2; public Figure(double val1, double val2){ v1 = val1; v2 = val2; } public Figure() { } public double getArea() { return v1 * v2; } }
(3) public class Figure { double v1, v2; public Figure(double val1, double val2){ v1 = val1; v2 = val2; } public Figure() { v1 = 0; v2 = 0; } public double getArea() { return v1 * v2; } }
(4) public class Figure { double v1, v2; public Figure(double val1, double val2){ v1 = val1; v2 = val2; } public Figure() { } public double getArea() { return val1 * val2; } }
questions.correctAnswer: (4) public class Figure { double v1, v2; public Figure(double val1, double val2){ v1 = val1; v2 = val2; } public Figure() { } public double getArea() { return val1 * val2; } }
questions.explanation: The variables val1 and val2 are not in scope inside getArea(); it should multiply the fields v1 and v2.

options: (1) Arrays.sort(names, Collections.reverseOrder()); for (int i = 0; i < names.length - 1; i++) display = display + names[i] + " ";
(2) Arrays.sort(names); for (int i = names.length - 1; i >= 0; i--) display = display + names[i] + " ";
(3) names.sort(); for (int i = names.length - 1; i >= 0; i--) display = display + names[i] + " ";
(4) Not one of the above. The compiler will give a NullPointerException error as some elements in the array have null values.
questions.correctAnswer: (4) Not one of the above. The compiler will give a NullPointerException error as some elements in the array have null values.
questions.explanation: Sorting the array without first initialising the remaining entries throws a NullPointerException.

options: (1) boolean error = false; int[] numbers = {1,2,4,5,3}; int sum = 0; for (int i = 1; i < 10; i++){ try { sum = sum + numbers[i]; } exception (Catch e) { error = true; } }
(2) boolean error = false; int[] numbers = {1,2,4,5,3}; int sum = 0; for (int i = 1; i < 10; i++){ try { sum = sum + numbers[i]; } catch (error = true;) }
(3) boolean error = false; int[] numbers = {1,2,4,5,3}; int sum = 0; for (int i = 1; i < 10; i++){ try { sum = sum + numbers[i]; } catch (Exception e) { error = true; } }
(4) boolean error = false; int[] numbers = {1,2,4,5,3}; int sum = 0; for (int i = 1; i < 10; i++){ Exception try { sum = sum + numbers[i]; } catch (Exception e) { error = true; } }
questions.correctAnswer: (3) boolean error = false; int[] numbers = {1,2,4,5,3}; int sum = 0; for (int i = 1; i < 10; i++){ try { sum = sum + numbers[i]; } catch (Exception e) { error = true; } }
questions.explanation: Wrapping the assignment in a try/catch and setting a flag when an exception occurs handles the out-of-bounds access gracefully.

options: (2) D Almost there keep up the hard work
(3) C Almost there keep up the hard work
questions.explanation: A mark of 64 falls in the "C" range and assigns message "Well done!".

questions.text: Indicate which one of the following code fragments can replace the above if...else statements and still render the same results.
options: (1) switch(test) { case 40: symbol = "F"; break; case 50: symbol = "E"; message = messages[1]; break; case 60: symbol = "D"; break; case 70: symbol = "C"; message = messages[2]; break; case 80: symbol = "B"; break; case 90: symbol = "A"; message = messages[1]; break; default: symbol = "A++"; }

(2) switch(test) { case < 40: symbol = "F"; break; case < 50: symbol = "E"; message = messages[1]; break; case < 60: symbol = "D"; break; case < 70: symbol = "C"; message = messages[2]; break; case < 80: symbol = "B"; break; case < 90: symbol = "A"; message = messages[1]; break; default: symbol = "A++"; }

(3) switch(test) { case in [0..39]: symbol = "F"; break; case in [40..49]: symbol = "E"; message = messages[1]; break; case in [50..59]: symbol = "D"; break; case in [60..69]: symbol = "C"; message = messages[2]; break; case in [70..79]: symbol = "B"; break; case in [80..89]: symbol = "A"; message = messages[1]; break; default: symbol = "A++"; }
questions.explanation: Java switch statements cannot express the range checks used in the if...else chain.

options: (1) users.txt will contain the following: Ann: passwordBen: 12345Cathy: Ql8jpL
(2) users.txt will contain the following: Ann: password / Ben: 12345 / Cathy: Ql8jpL
(3) users.txt will contain the following: username: password / username: 12345 / username: Ql8jpL
(4) users.txt will be empty since the file has not been opened before attempting to write.
questions.correctAnswer: (1) users.txt will contain the following: Ann: passwordBen: 12345Cathy: Ql8jpL
questions.explanation: toString returns "username: password" and no line separators are written, so the entries run together.

questions.text: Code fragments that read from and write to files need to handle at least the checked exceptions to avoid compiler errors. Which one of the following options will handle the checked exceptions in the code above?
options: (3) public void writeToFile() throws FileException, IOException { ... }
questions.explanation: FileWriter and BufferedWriter operations can throw IOException, which covers the checked exceptions raised.

questions.text:
Which one of the following statements is FALSE regarding the programming language Java?
Java is a(n) ___ computer programming language.
questions.explanation: Java is designed to be platform independent via the JVM.

questions.text: Which of the following is an INVALID variable name in Java?
questions.explanation: Identifiers may not begin with a digit, making option 1 invalid.
